questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with easy fatigability and jaundice for the last 1 month. had similar episodes in the past. On examination, he is found to have splenomegaly. MCHC is 44 g/dl. On ultrasound examination, he is found to have gallstones. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Severe forms are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner

options.label: B
options.text: ANK-1 mutations account for the majority of this condition

options.label: C
options.text: SLC2A1 mutations are associated with ovalocytosis and cause cardiovascular severe complications

options.label: D
options.text: All the above statements are true

questions.correct_answer: C. SLC2A1 mutations are associated with ovalocytosis and cause cardiovascular severe complications
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SLC2A1 mutations are associated with ovalocytosis and cause cardiovascular severe complications The clinical features and history are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis(HS) . Points favoring diagnosis -Presentation of a child with anemia, jaundice and splenomegaly is indicative of a congenital hemolytic anemia elevated MCHC is a significant point in favor of the clinical diagnosis The presence of gallstones should trigger suspicion of Hereditary spherocytosis. mutations of the SLC2A1 gene(mutation in GLUT1 Glucose transporter) on Chr 1p34 leads to overhydrated hereditary stomatocytosis and is associated with severe neurological manifestations

Highyeild:

Mutation in ANKYRIN, Band 3 – spherocytosis Mutation in Band 3–ovalocytosis Mutation in Spectrin–Elliptocytosis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. It has been recognised that the inheritance of HS is not always Autosomal dominant, and some of the most severe forms are Autosomal recessive. Ankyrin and Band 3 mutations –Autosomal dominant form of hereditary spherocytosis. Spectrin Band 4.2 mutations –Autosomal dominant form of Hereditary Spherocytosis. Option: B. ANK-1 gene mutations that code for Ankyrin may account for most HS.

Extraedge:

A classification for HS has been developed based on the severity of anemia and markers of hemolysis (reticulocyte count and bilirubin) HS trait – Normal hemoglobin, bilirubin, and reticulocyte count Mild HS (20 to 30 percent of cases) – Hemoglobin 11 to 15 g/dL; reticulocytes 3 to 6 percent; bilirubin 1 to 2 mg/dL (from 17 to 34 micromol/L) Moderate HS (60 to 75 percent of cases) – Hemoglobin 8 to 12 g/dL; reticulocytes >6 per cent; bilirubin >2 mg/dL (>34 micromol/L) Severe HS (5 per cent of cases) – Hemoglobin 6 to 8 g/dL; reticulocytes >10 per cent; bilirubin >3 mg/dL (>51 micromol/L)

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents to medicine OPD, distressed that he “passed blood instead of urine” yesterday. CBC done showed pancytopenia. LDH is 1100 IU/L. Haptoglobin is undetectable. Direct and indirect Coombs test is negative Treatment of this condition is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eculizumab The patient has presented hemoglobinuria and features of haemolytic anemia. DCT is negative He also has pancytopenia and elevated LDH . All these findings make the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria compelling. Treatment of PNH:- Long-term hemolysis glucocorticoids are not indicated as they do not affect chronic hemolysis. They are contraindicated as their side effects are considerable. Short-term prednisone may be helpful when an inflammatory process exacerbates hemolysis. Best treatment = Bone marrow transplantation. The best treatment to prevent chronic hemolysis or clot formation = Eculizumab Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to the complement protein C5, thus inhibiting terminal complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis in PNH patients. The only treatment that currently can provide a definitive cure for PNH is allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: B, C & D are not the correct options for treatment in PNH.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

G6PD enzyme is required to convert glucose 6 phosphate to 6 phosphogluconolactone , producing This is required to keep Glutathione in the reduced state to prevent oxygen damage to the RBC. questions.text: A 43-year-old male suddenly passed out blood instead of urine. Routine check-ups revealed he had anemia. After some days of deteriorating conditions, he was diagnosed with acute hepatomegaly. Further blood tests revealed liver function tests are normal. What will you do next?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eculizumab Eculizumab and Ravulizumab are monoclonal antibodies against c5 used in the treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. The clinical symptom of sudden onset blood instead of urine and the diagnosis of acute hepatomegaly with no underlying liver disease suggest PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria). Intracorpuscular acquired cause of intravascular hemolysis. Patients generally present with episodic early morning Hematuria. A significant advancement in treating this disease is the introduction of a monoclonal antibody Eculizumab in 2007. This antibody binds to the complement component c5 near the site that, when cleaved, will trigger the formation of the MAC. With the c5 blocked, there is no intravascular hemolysis. Hence for many PNH patients, Eculizumab is a real improvement in quality of life with reduced associated complications, especially thrombosis. A. Allogenic BMT This is a definitive cure with the cost of non-negligible risks, but the latter is more effective after the discovery of Eculizumab in 2007. B. Continue supportive treatment This is required for patients who cannot afford Eculizumab because it is expensive and accessible in many parts of the world. D. Long term glucocorticoids Not indicated because there is no evidence that it has any effect on chronic hemolysis.

questions.text: The patient with von Willebrand disease is about to undergo a root canal procedure. What should be done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Desmopressin Von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. It is due to a deficiency of VWF. The mainstay of treatment in VWD is ddavp (desmopressin). can be given intravenously or intranasally. It is recommended for patients with VWD. Ddavp can be tested in the laboratory for their response; in patients who respond well, it can be used in procedures with minor to moderate risk of bleeding, like before root canal surgery or any dental procedures

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A- This is an antifibrinolytic drug, next in line after ddavp and is used to prevent mucosal bleeding. It is contraindicated in the setting of upper urethral bleeding due to the risk of urethral obstruction. Option: C- Used for major procedures and not in minor procedures like dental procedures. Option: D- This is an antifibrinolytic drug next in line after ddavp. It is used to prevent mucosal bleeding, particularly useful in treating heavy menstrual bleeding (TXA 1300 mg every 8 h) and postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida in the first trimester presents with extreme fatigue, pallor, and icterus. She reports being previously healthy. On evaluation, her hemoglobin is 8 g/dL with a normal MCV and an elevated MCHC, reticulocyte count is 9%, indirect bilirubin is 4.9 mg/dL, and serum haptoglobin is not detectable. Her peripheral smear is shown in the image. Her physical examination is notable for splenomegaly and a normal 3-month uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hereditary spherocytosis The peripheral blood smear shows micro spherocytes, small densely staining red blood cells that have lost their central pallor characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis. Spherocytosis is almost the only condition with an increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Hereditary spherocytosis is a heterogeneous RBC membranopathy that can be either congenital (usually autosomal dominant ) or acquired; it is characterised by predominantly extravascular hemolysis in the spleen caused by defects in membrane structural proteins. This spleen-mediated hemolysis leads to converting classic biconcave RBCs on smear to spherocytes. Splenomegaly is common. Acute treatment is with transfusion.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Chronic gastrointestinal blood loss, such as caused by a colonic polyp, would cause microcytic, hypochromic anemia without evidence of hemolysis (indirect bilirubin, haptoglobin abnormalities). Option: B. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is a cause of hemolysis usually triggered by an offending oxidative agent. peripheral blood smear may show Heinz's body. Option: D. Parvovirus infection may cause a pure RBC aplasia. The presence of active reticulocytosis and laboratory findings consistent with hemolysis are incompatible with that diagnosis.

questions.text: Splenectomy is indicated in all of the following conditions in hereditary spherocytosis EXCEPT:
questions.correct_answer: B. An episode of hemolytic crisis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

An episode of hemolytic crisis Splenectomy is indicated in all of the following conditions in hereditary spherocytosis: Anemia causing health impairment Recurrent hemolytic crisis Aplastic crisis (percolated by Parvovirus) Evidence of cholecystitis/gallstones In mild cases, avoid splenectomy; in moderate cases, delay splenectomy until puberty; in severe cases, proceed with splenectomy at the age of 4–6.

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about precautions during splenectomy in hereditary spherocytosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Pneumococcal vaccine should be given 1 month before splenectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Daily penicillin should be prescribed for at least 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: Blood transfusion should be done in a severe hemorrhagic crisis

options.label: D
options.text: Along with splenectomy, cholecystectomy should be carried out

questions.correct_answer: D. Along with splenectomy, cholecystectomy should be carried out
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Along with splenectomy, cholecystectomy should be carried out. Precautions during splenectomy in hereditary spherocytosis: The pneumococcal vaccine should be given 1 month before splenectomy. Daily penicillin should be prescribed for at least 5 years (penicillin prophylaxis after splenectomy is controversial). Blood transfusion should be done in severe hemorrhagic crises. Along with splenectomy, cholecystectomy should not be carried out automatically; it should be carried out, usually by the laparoscopic approach, when clinically indicated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B & C are true.

questions.text: Which statements are false about hereditary spherocytosis and proteins of RBC membrane?

options.label: A
options.text: glycophorin protein is associated with hereditary spherocytosis

options.label: B
options.text: Most abundant integral protein in the RBC membrane is Glycophorin

options.label: C
options.text: Most SEVERE deficiency in HS is Ankyrin deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Most commonly deficient protein in HS is an ankyrin

questions.correct_answer: C. Most SEVERE deficiency in HS is Ankyrin deficiency
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most SEVERE deficiency in HS is Ankyrin deficiency Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by inherited defects in the membrane skeleton, a network of proteins stabilizing the red cell's lipid bilayer. The primary membrane skeleton protein is spectrin , a long, flexible heterodimer that self-associates at one end and binds short actin filaments at its other end. These contacts create a two-dimensional meshwork connected to the transmembrane proteins band 3 and glycophorin via the linker proteins ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 4.1.

Extraedge:

The most abundant integral protein in the RBC membrane is Glycophorin, But it is NEVER involved in Hereditary spherocytosis. Most SEVERE deficiency in Hereditary Spherocytosis (a most SEVERE form of HS) is Spectrin deficiency , an autosomal recessive form of hereditary spherocytosis. The most commonly deficient protein in Hereditary spherocytosis is ankyrin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most specific test for diagnosing Hereditary Spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

E9013sin-5-maleimide test Flow cytometry-based test, which uses the fluorescent dye EOSIN-5-MALEIMIDE (EMA), is now considered to have a specificity of 94-99%. It is a better test than osmotic fragility.EMA is a dye that binds to the band3 region of the RBC membrane. Hence patients with hereditary spherocytosis will show a lower fluorescence intensity than normal RBCs.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B & C. are not explicitly compared to the eosin -5- maleimide test Option: D. NESTROFT as a screening test for detection of Beta-thalassemia trait.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman came to the hospital with complaints of weakness and fatigue. Examination revealed splenomegaly. Her Hb was 6gm/l, and her reticulocyte count was high. Her Iron profile came normal, but MCHC was high. Nucleated RBCs and micro spherocytes with no central pallor are seen on peripheral smear. What is the best possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hereditary spherocytosis HS On smears, spherocytes are dark red and lack central pallor . The excessive red cell destruction and resultant anemia lead to compensatory hyperplasia of red cell progenitors in the marrow and an increase in red cell production marked by Splenomegaly is more common and prominent in hereditary spherocytosis than in any other form of hemolytic anemia. The other general features of hemolytic anemia also are present, including cholelithiasis, which occurs in 40% to 50% of patients with hereditary spherocytosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, C & D - We can eliminate these three by clinical features of this patient. Iron deficiency - patients will improve on treatment with oral iron, and splenomegaly should not usually be present. G6PD deficiency will present with PS showing Heinz bodies and bite cells. AIHA will have a positive Coombs test .

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with anemia. Her peripheral blood smear and blood count are done, and a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis is made. The physician has advised Splenectomy. Which of the following is the reason for this?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above There is no way to correct the primary defect in the membrane-cytoskeleton structure. Given the special role of the spleen in HS, it has long been thought that splenectomy was an almost obligatory therapeutic measure . In mild cases–no treatment is required. In moderate cases(significant anemia and Gallstones) - splenectomy can be done at puberty. In severe cases, splenectomy at the age of 4–6. Antipneumococcal vaccination before splenectomy is imperative. Along with splenectomy, cholecystectomy should not be carried out if there is no cholelithiasis at the splenectomy. Splenectomy as an indication for treatment: severe anemia Causes health impairment Recurrent hemolytic crisis Aplastic crisis (percolated by Parvovirus)

questions.text: A 27-year-old man of northern European lineage presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. After his lab investigations, diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis is made. Which of the following is true about hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of hemolytic state In HS, the splenic capillaries cannot modify their shape during RBC( due to membrane cytoskeletal defects). Speen modifies the membrane of RBC to have the least surface area to volume ratio(sphere).due to this, excessive destruction of RBCs is prevented. Abnormal red cells with decreased membrane surface area and increased sphericity are trapped in the spleen and phagocytosed. MCV is reduced in reticulocytes as well. MCHC is increased Erythropoiesis is stimulated due to red cell destruction, which is done by EPO released from the kidney. This maintains a balance between destruction n production. Here the hemolysis is said to be compensated . Hence no anemia in compensated hemolysis. This anemia can become decompensated anemia and may suddenly reappear in cases like pregnancy, folate deficiency, and renal failure.
